print_settings.Notes:: I used a raft to ensure that the bottom layer didn't have any lines in (I'm using tape on the bed), as these will show whilst shining light through the print.

description.text:
Starting a night light for my daughter, and decided to make a princess surround. Thus this .stl - Not to pretty to look at, but hold it up to the light and.... look how it changes. It allows light through and looks amazing.

Give me a shout if you have a request to do a different one

Check out my other designs:
Thing: 2367661 - Snow White
Thing: 2366519 - Ariel
Thing: 2370781 - Rapunzel
Thing: 2380001 - Frame

Printer:

CR-10

Rafts:

Yes

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

Layer 0.1000mm

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Using Standard White PLA:

S3D Settings
Retraction: 6.5mm (1800mm/min speed)

Layer: 1st:H 120% W 150%
1st layer speed 50%

Temp: Bed: 40
Extruder: 215

Speed: 2600.00 mm/min

I used a raft to ensure that the bottom layer didn't have any lines in (I'm using tape on the bed), as these will show whilst shining light through the print.

There should be no need for post-printing finishing. Although if stringing has occurred remove.

Hold up to the light and see the extra detail not visible on print itself!

Imported an image into Cura (i found that it was best to use a transparent image to ensure that no unwanted background parts would be included) and adjusted its setting to ensure that print would allow light to shine through. Resized the image (to match my requirements - be careful at this stage not to increase the overall thickness, as this will reduce the light pass through). I'm sure at this stage Cura would be able to print the file, however i saved it as an .obj and exported it to S3D (preferred software). Then printed
Neutral PLA

comments.text:
I was used Slic3r for slicing (with enabled "spiral vase" option and only one perimeter).
If you not use "spiral vase" option, maybe you can choose eg. number of top layer =0, numb. of perimeters = 1, bottom layers = 3

title: StarWars TieFighter Gen2
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
Deutsch:

Nach dem TieFighter Gen1 von Ende 2015 wollte ich vergangenes Jahr eine neue Version machen, welche einfacher umzusetzen ist. Ausserdem sollten keine sichtbaren Kabel mehr vorhanden sein. Herausgekommen ist der Gen2. Aber wie es so ist, das reale Leben geht weiter und ich kam bis jetzt nicht dazu, die neue Version online zu stellen. Jetzt aber…

Ich nutze ganz normale Materialen und Komponenten, wie sie jeder Modellbauer zu Hause hat. Eigentlich sollte alles selbsterklärend sein, aber ich hab ein kurzes Montagevideo zusammengeschnitten unter https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rvou3XwCeqw&t=180s.

Je nach Controller kann die Längsstabilität resp. Windempfindlichkeit problematisch werden. Ich hab hierzu einfach die Winglets ohne Deckschichten und mit einem Infill von 45% gedruckt.

Viel Spass allen, die einen nachbauen wollen. Ich hoffe es passt alles zur Zufriedenheit…

Ein kleines Flugvideo gibts hier: https://youtu.be/2D95EzOs3RY

English:

After my TieFighter Gen1 I wanted to do a new and simplified version. In addition, there also shouldn’t be any visible cables anymore. After a few weeks Gen2 was done. But as it is, real life goes on and I haven’t get any time to put it online. Until now….

I use quite normal materials and components as every model builder should have at home. Actually the whole building should be self-explanatory, but I made a short assembling video here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=Rvou3XwCeqw&t=180s

Depending on the controller, the longitudinal stability (sensitivity) could cost some troubles. Therefor I’ve printed the Winglets without cover layers and with an infill of something around 45%.

Have fun! I hope it fits all for your satisfaction…

Some Flightfootage you’ll find here : https://youtu.be/2D95EzOs3RY

Printer:

ZYYX 3D Printer

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

10% - 45%

Notes:

Print the winglets without top/bottom layer and with something about 45% infill.

description.text:
Customizable wire clips, for attaching either speaker wire (flat) or coax (rounded) to baseboards, walls etc. Design is based on standard clips you can find in hardware stores, but these are made to measure, and can be printed in any color or material you need.

Measure the height and width of the wire you need to secure and enter them into the customizer. Also choose how wide and strong you want the clips to be, size of nail being used, and between the single or dual nail variants.

Nails need to be purchased separately, or take them from the hundreds of clips you already have that are the wrong size for the job.

Printer:

Prusa i3 Mk2S

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Notes:

Print in ABS or Nylon for strength, but for normal use, PLA seems to work fine indoors. Or simply choose whatever material you have that is the correct color to blend in with the wire or wall.
Take care removing small clips from the bed, the side of the clip without the nail can break off.

Hercules, arrived at New Romney on 20th April 1927. It is similar to its Pacific cousins, but is slightly longer and have smaller driving wheels.
Hercules hauled the inaugural train from Hythe on the opening day of the line - July 16th 1927.
By the time that the railway was commandeered by the Army she was fit to find fame as the engine used for the armoured train during World War Two.

Hey Space World -- I'm the Principal Investigator of the NASA Psyche Mission, and I hope you are interested in playing with our Psyche model -- get creative! We've never seen the metal world Psyche as more than a point of light, but in 2022, we are launching a NASA mission to visit and learn about it. Peter Rubin and I worked together for a couple of years to make a model of Psyche that incorporates both the best shape model for the body that has been created using radar from Arecibo Observatory (Shepard+ 2017) and details of the surface, including faults and craters, based on our best existing physical and chemical models. When we get to Psyche in 2026, we'll find out how close we were! Check out the videos on https://www.nasa.gov/psyche and the big 3D print here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2bxrruz_Dxk !

description.text: This is a housing for the mp3-player, 2x RCA sockets to connect to the external speakers and a 18650 battery to power the bicycle lights. Many of us have an old mp3-player somewhere in a box with an old stuff. You are free to use this model to adapt it to your own player.

Wanhao

Wanhao Duplicator i3 V2

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed with SBS.

The idea was to make a new housing for the old Mpio ML300 mp3-player which had a broken battery holder cover. Then I found a couple of 2W / 4Ohm 3" speakers and I thought, why not make a bicycle stereo since the using of headphones is dangerous. Then I thought of using the 18650 battery from the old laptop battery to power front and rear lights as well. And then I decided this player should be easily detachable since leaving electronics attached to the handlebar outside is not clever. I've gone through several iterations and several sleepless nights before the final version was printed out. So I'm glad I'm done with this project.

The housing contains:
  • the player itself with a DIY printed board power source (AMS1117-1.8);
  • 18650 battery with a holder;
  • PJ002 power socket; TP4056 charger;
  • PAM8403 amplifier;
  • 2x slide switches;
  • 2x RCA sockets.

title: D-bot X/Y motion system linear guide blocks and pads made from Igus tribofilament

description.text:
Note: I just posted a version 2.0 of these Igus-filament slider blocks and pads here:
https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2444422
Version 2.0 offers a more refined shape for the carrier blocks that blends better with the original D-bot parts. The version 2.0 sliding pads use less Igus material and reduce the surface contact area between the pads and the v-slot rail. I don't consider version 2.0 as a necessary upgrade for anyone who has already made and installed the version 1.0, though it may well perform better over time due to the improved slider pads. The carrier block changes are entirely cosmetic.

Hi. I removed all of the V-slot mini wheels from my D-bot's X/Y motion system and replaced them with sliding blocks that are lined with pads printed from Igus tribofilament. This system consists of a block which uses the same hole spacing as the D-bot gantry end caps and also the print carriage plates. The block is the same width as the two spacers and the mini v-slot wheels used in the D-bot design. To this block is applied a bearing pad printed from Igus tribofilament, which rides on both the 20mm wide flat surface of the 2040 V-slot rail, but also fits down into the V-shaped slot to keep things nicely aligned.

The purpose for using these blocks is:

1) Tighter fit between the print carriage and the 2040 v-slot print gantry, and between the ends of the gantry and the 2040 v-slot printer frame side rails. With these mounted fairly tightly there is no detectable play or slop in the system at all. Zero.

2) Low friction for a fully contacting sliding pad system. There was more friction in the moving parts as compared to the ball-bearing mini v-slot wheels, but I presume that this will smooth out in time as the parts "wear in" to each other. Also that friction is not necessarily a bad thing, as it could likely act as a sort of dampener that could reduce ringing. The steppers in a D-bot are plenty powerful enough to move these things around, so a slight dampening effect I see as a positive.

3) Long service life. I fully expect these pads to last longer than the rest of the D-bot itself. Igus advertises that their tribofilament wears up to 50 times less than other printable plastics. Their charts seem to bear that out, but then they would, wouldn't they?

4) The pads don't stick out beyond the ends of the plates the way the v-slot mini wheels do, so the pad blocks can move on the Y axis all the way up to the rear idler corner blocks of the frame. This means that the Y axis end stop screw has no problem getting to the Y axis end stop switch. With the mini V-slot wheels I had to bend the switch lever of the Y axis end stop switch out a little in order to get contact with the end stop screw. This seems like a trivial benefit, but was actually quite a nice little bonus to those of us whose end stop screws just didn't quite reach the switch.

I've been wanting to try the Igus filament for some time, and seeing quite a few people create D-bot mods that involve bolting Hiwin linear guide rods to their D-bot's top rails and print gantry inspired me to create this. I want the same benefits of the Hiwin linear guide system, without adding all of the weight of the Hiwin rails and sliding blocks, and while being much cheaper. One of the aspects of the D-bot design that really appeals to me is how the D-bot frame itself, because it's made using the OpenBuilds v-slot rails, can act as the guide rail for the Z and X/Y motion systems. The Hiwin solutions are adding tons of crap to the D-bot, and especially when you add the Hiwin rails and blocks to the 2040 print gantry of the stock D-bot design, you're adding quite a lot of weight to it that I just think is unnecessary and likely detrimental.

I've had these sliding blocks installed for going on a month of printing as of this posting, and my printer is busy for most of nearly every single day. So far these blocks have worked out great. Because the pads are designed to the exact dimension of the outer flat surface, and the V-slot itself, of the OpenBuilds V-Slot rails that the D-bot's framing is made of, they are a decently tight fit, and yet because they are printed from Igus's tribofilament, they will probably last forever, and show very low friction. It's not no friction, but the friction is surprisingly low for such full contact

My original idea for these used two shorter pads at either end of the sliding block, rather than a full-length pad, in order to minimize the surface contact area of the Igus material on the aluminum v-slot rail to drop friction even more, but it was more difficult than I'd assumed it would be to get all four pads (two each for top and bottom block per side) exactly aligned with each other. The full length pads fit down onto the tangs printed into the top surface of the blocks allowed extremely good alignment of the pads.

As printed, since I use a Bowden feed on my D-bot, I had slight blobbing at the corners that required a couple of minutes' worth of cleanup with an Xacto knife. Depending on how you print these, how the first layer goes down, etc. you may have to do some minor trimming to get the pads to snap down onto the tangs on the block. I left the tolerances extremely tight, tighter than you'd reasonably expect to achieve with a 3D print, specifically so that the pads would be exactly aligned on the bearing pads, and would be a good, tight fit in the v-slot slots.

Once printed and test fit to each other, I put a few drops of CA (super glue) onto the Igus filament pad bottoms, snapped them onto the blocks, and then clamped them down pretty hard onto a section of spare 2040 Vslot rail that I have left over from my D-bot. I left them clamped hard like this for a couple hours until I was sure the CA was dry.

I printed the blocks from PETG at 97% infill. I printed the pads from Igus tribofilament i170 at 70% infill with 3 perimeters in order to save material. I used 7 top layers at .1mm layer height, for fine resolution on the pads' bearing surfaces.

I've also tried the i180 filament. The 180 filament prints easier, and the prints look better, but it seems somehow softer than the 170, and the 170 also seems to have less friction. Igus claims in their marketing materials that 170 has the best wear behavior, but is more demanding of production technique. I can vouch for at least the second part of that.

I printed the Igus pads at 260 C with the bed at 90 C. I used a brim to lock it down after several attempts pealed up from my PEI sheet a little in one or two corners. I removed the brim with an Xacto knife afterward. I also used a brim on the main PETG blocks for the same reason.

This is version 1.0 of this item. My intent was to clean up the design of the blocks so they blend in better with the existing D-bot print carriage plates and the gantry bar end plates. I haven't done that refinement yet, but someone asked me for these files, so I'm putting it up now as is so they can be used. When I've refined the block design I'll post that updated block as 2.0. The change will only be cosmetic. While these blocks look fine as is, they can look better if I tweak the dimensions slightly and add a radius to the bottom ends of the block so they match the radius on the corners of the stock D-bot plates.

Here's a short Youtube video that I made showing this system in use on my D-bot:
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ChPcBsqxBR4&feature=youtu.be

I'm attaching my SolidWorks 2016 source files for both blocks and pads. All of this is released with the Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial license.

comments.text: The Igus filament doesn't have a lot of strength in tension. Under compression it's fine. Since trying to make an insert with it that would fit the inside of the slot area would result in it being pulled (in tension) I don't think it would last. Both the I170 and the I180 would delaminate. My pads and other Igus bearings work because things are being pressed against the rail surfaces, not pulled.

description.text:
Whilst working on a night light for my daughter, with a princess surround. I was asked to create other character versions.

Not to pretty to look at, but hold it up to the light and.... look how it changes. It allows light through and looks amazing.

Note: At present I have not printed this file and are therefore not able to provide feedback about how it will look. I did however use the same process as my other creations - see things below for finished examples

If anyone does print this before i get the chance please let me know if any adjustments are required, Thanks

Give me a shout if you have a request to do a different one.

Check out my other designs:
Thing: 2367661 - Snow White
Thing: 2370781 - Rapunzel (Tangled - Disney)
Thing: 2373408 - Belle

Imported an image into Cura (i found that it was best to use a transparent image to ensure that no unwanted background parts would be included) and adjusted its setting to ensure that print would allow light to shine through. Resized the image (to match my requirements - be careful at this stage not to increase the overall thickness, as this will reduce the light pass through). I'm sure at this stage Cura would be able to print the file, however i saved it as an .obj and exported it to S3D (preferred software)

This is a pencil model that I made specifically for multimaterial printing.
I printed the pieces vertically using simplify 3d on a dual extrusion flashforge dreamer. Print was specifically modeled in a way so that while one material is printing solid, the other material could be swapped out, to actually print the model using 5 different materials and colors.

The actual one was printed using ninjaflex pink for the eraser, inland gray pla for the metal eraser ferrell, hatchbox pla yellow pencil body, esun woodfil for wooden sharpened part of pencil, and inland black for the graphite tip.

title: bondtech bmg extruder carriage robo R1+

description.text:
2/7/18 UPDATE,
i have made changes to improve the vertical rigidness that was causing issue during the 9 point level and throwing off the z offset in an unpredictable manner. the unit now has a removable plate to make it easier to remove the hotend and extruder assembly, a beefier cable harness that wont crack as easily and easier access to the bottom right mounting screw through an opening in the belt tensioning platform
any feed back is appreciated to help make more imporvments

 9/30/17 update.

i have found that pla works best so far, both petg and abs flexed to much when it was doing the autolevel routine, even with mesh leveling. the pla frame had a bit more rigidity which is important.

6/22/17 update
I am working on a new version to allow the standard sized stepper motor, the pancake stepper is have problems overheating.

i have been looking at bondtech extruders for a while and finally decided to go for it and get the bond tech BMG extruder. i didn't want to do a bowden setup so i decided to remix Mike Kelly's replacement x carriage.

The x carriage assembly with dual fans and hotend is 300g lighter then the stock robo set up with E3Dv6 and dual part fans. i also had to remix the fan shrouds so that the hot end would clear the bottom of them. if someone knows who the original designer of the fan shroud is please let me know so i can link to them.

all the clearances are tight in order to have it all work together so patience and very tight tolerance control is needed.

Here is a link to the linear bearings I used,
OTRMAX 4-Piece 8mm Longer Linear Motion Ball Bearing Double Side Rubber Seal Linear Bushing CNC Part LM8LUU https://www.amazon.com/dp/B01MXTYSVL/ref=cm_sw_r_cp_tai_ztHozb08ACK56

Several of our students, as a result of their special needs, require accommodation to help manage their socioemotional attitudes and behaviours. One of our Learning Assistants approached me to create a discrete communication tool for a young student to track shifts in emotional reactions.

Jackson Witte created this: https://tinkercad.com/things/l58thpZjvWF (Attribution-Share-Alike Unported 3.0) which served as a template to adjust using Tinkercad. Notes:

I chose to use CMYK as my colour template for the PLA.

Clean Up

The addition of a raft to support the die on the bed meant I needed to file down the "5" side. The dice itself remains fairly well-balanced nevertheless.

Why Print This? Not all things need to be communicated verbally. Students may not be able to say exactly how they feel, but they can perhaps point to where they feel on a spectrum of feelings. Using dice to represent feelings can facilitate the process of having students identify frustrations, emotions, reactions, or attitudes as they experience important moments in the classroom. Should we choose to track students' reactions it is possible, over time, to develop a sense of how a student is learning to cope with the dynamics of a classroom. Three areas we have identified where a student might need to communicate that they need support are; a) Group Work, b) Focus, c) Stress/Anxiety particularly if they have been identified as requiring special accommodation within a classroom. We have taken those areas and turned them into a 5-point scale for a student to silently indicate how they are feeling.

Using the Likert Scale A student first needs to be able to identify what the numbers mean to them on a personal scale using examples of when they have felt that way, or how they can identify someone who might be feeling that way. For instance, using the yellow "Group Die" a student would indicate that a 1 might mean that group work is happening and there are no issues arising, the group is working well together. A five might mean that the student has had an extremely negative reaction to working for this group and has shut them out. Data Collection Once the student is familiar with the scales they have created for how they feel for each die. They then use the Dice Deck to keep track through a class of the changes in how "Focus", "Stress" or "Group Work" is changing. A teacher or aide can now check-in visually with the student and even create a graph of the numbers the student is communicating in a journal for that student. (This is done in the instance that it is difficult for a student to keep their own journal). Data Analysis If a comprehensive journal is kept it should be possible over time for the student and counsellor to recognise 'triggers' for emotional changes, and identify "strategies" that have worked to mitigate their negative emotional responses. A graph of the data and notes on nodes on that graph would facilitate this. The intentional practice of this should serve to increase student resiliency, increase personal wellness, and promote metacognitive awareness. Where I'd Like to See This Go I think that the deck could be altered to become interactive with the dice. Once you put a die down on the surface it should be possible to identify which number is up, and then log an input in a chronological database so that no one has to actually take down numbers.

Using Therapy Dice I have not been able to find physical references to support the use of therapy dice. I am relying on the experience and advice of our local counsellors and the examples of similar activities found online. Please comment below if you know of resources worth adding to this work, or suggestions for other dice that might be useful.

title: CodeCreations Drywall Repair / Patch Clips
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I had to cut a hole in my drywall to make a repair, and I wanted to patch it with the same piece I took out -- it was already just about the right size. 
I designed these clips to meet this need. They're PLA and so a little inflexible, but the patch snapped right into place by wedging one side in, and then giving the opposite clip a solid whack. 
The surface is flush, and the repair is solid. Next I just need to get out the drywall compound and finish it up. 
I need to clean up the OpenSCAD code a bit (and make it parametric), and then I'll post it as well. Meantime, here is the STL for a single clip and a set of four. 
Total cost of plastic: About 5 cents. :) Reprap rocks!

(File and version details below instructions.) 1) Print clips. 2) Cut a couple layers off the surface of the patch and the adjoining wall (where the clip will be installed) so that the clips and patch will be flush. 3) Install the clips onto the patch, and press into place on the wall. I wedged one side in first, and then gave the opposite clip a firm (but not too hard) whack, and it just snapped solidly into place. 4) Finish with drywall compound. 5) Call your spouse over to see the repair, and remind him/her of what a good investment the 3D printer was. Some file and update notes: DrywallClip.stl is a single clip with 1mm thick material.
DrywallClipx4.stl is for of the 1mm think clips, spaced out a bit for printing all at once.
DrywallClipx4.8.stl uses clips that are a bit thinner (0.8mm as opposed to 1mm) but still slices properly on slic3r (which still has a problem with thin wall forked paths) using a 0.5mm nozzle. I'll test this version after I poke a new hole in my wall. They should "give" a bit more.

description.text:
This is a remix of https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2219963 to allow mounting a BLTouch sensor on the rear bearing of an Anet A8. I've included the customizer to allow the height
and many other features to be custom set for any printer . The "Measured Height" parameter is used to calculate the correct height with the 8.3mm offset to the nozzle. You simply need to move the print nozzle so that it touches the bed then measure the distance of top mount screw hole (on the rear lower bearing) to the bed. Enter this in the "measured height" field and create. The mount also includes side clearance to allow it to work on new Anet A8's. Please note that for this mount, you need a mount to bed distance of at least 44.8mm (sensor height + 8.3) or it won't work.

Uses 4 3x10mm bolts for both the sensor and backplate mounting

description.text:
Let me introduce the highly customizable lamp shade. After serveral days of programming and tests, you are able to create countless different lamp shades.

  • You can create a cone, cylinder, cube, sphere, pyramid, star, flower and a dodecahedron shape. These are only the shapes I could find, but there are much more shapes to discover.
  • You can customize different sizes and the hole for the bulb bracket.
  • You can create a lamp shade as a ceiling lamp or a desk lamp or for a different purpose like a nice bowl or a vase.
  • You can view some examples in the pictures above.

You can use the Thingiverse Customizer or OpenSCAD to create your lamp shade. If you need a more detailed preview of the lamp shade, I recommend you using OpenSCAD. The Scad-File is well documented to using it in OpenSCAD.

The light blue lamp socket, that I'm using together with this lamp shade is this silicone one with a long sleeved cable (picture 1 and 2). It is available in different colors: https://goo.gl/4Lx9Ux
The diameter of the bracket is 42mm.

I recommend you to use LED light bulbs, otherwise the lamp shade could melt. For the setup in the picture, I use 3x 2W Osram filament bulbs. This equals in total a 75W bulb.

Please share your customized lamp shades to the community! I would love to see them!

Supports:

No

Infill:

no

Notes:

Print the bottom with 3 or 4 Layers and the rest in spiral- or vase-mode. For a sleeve only print without bottom layers.
Carefull ,crossed patterns sometimes generate parts on the contour that make holes.
Use sharp knive to cut th holes in the bottom.
Openscad is the right thing for this.

Using Customizer

First think what you want, get your measurements. Think about how high you want to make each of the 4 parts to get your totalheight. Does it need holes for venting, should it fit on an adapter???
The printersettings are used for the holes to cutout. Carefull ,crossed patterns sometimes generate parts on the contour that make holes, this does matter if your extensions are long, not crossed patterns should always be printable. When you add too many slices it could generate a very big file.

FEATURES

/ [Features] /
//crossed or not, mirror the pattern
crossed = "no"; // [yes,no]
//Lower Ring
ring_low = "yes"; // [yes,no]
//Upper Ring
ring_up = "yes"; // [yes,no]
//Bottom cut shift, 0 for none, used only when ring
bottomshift = 1;
//Top cut shift, 0 for none, used only when ring
topshift =1;

//Inside Diameter
diameter = 60;
//Adapterholediameter, 0 for none
adaptersize = 10;
//Ventingholesdiameter, 0 for none
venthole = 4;
//Number of Ventholes
num_ventholes = 3;
//Bottom Height
bottomheight = 10;
//Lower Middle Height
lowmiddleheight = 15;
//Upper Middle Height
upmiddleheight = 15;
//Top Height
topheight = 10;

/ [Extensions] /
//Number of extensions
num_extensions = 40;
//Angle of Extensions, the more the thicker the extensions
angle_extension = 6;//[1:30]
//Offset of Extensions
offset_extension = 4;

/ [Twist] /
//Bottom Twist Angle
bottomtwist = 15;//[-80:80]
//Lower Middle Twist Angle
lowmiddletwist = -40;//[-80:80]
//Upper Middle Twist Angle
upmiddletwist = 40;//[-80:80]
//Top Twist Angle
toptwist = -15;//[-80:80]
//Middle slices
slices = 5;//[0:200]

/ [Printersettings] /
//Layer, Height of Layer, used for cutouts
layer = 0.2;
//Nozzle or Wallthicknes
nozzle = 0.4;

print_settings.Notes:: Most parts have holes covered with 0.3mm skin to aid in bridging and remove need for support. Slic3r detects these nicely and bridges over them, not sure for other slicers. Remove/punch thru the skin to clear the hole prior to assembly.

description.text:
Functionally complete. Screw lengths and quantities in BOM may need adjustment.

Specs:

MGN12 linear rails on all axes for accuracy and space savings. 5 rails are used- 1 for x, 2 for y, and 2 for z, hence '5RAILS'. The printer sports a healthy 300mm x 300mm x 350mm print envelope, a 500W heated bed using a 120VAC solid state relay, dual z non-cantilevered lift on TR8x8 trapezoidal leadscrews driven by single z stepper motor, dual e3D Titan direct drive (non bowden) extruders, non crossing X and Y belts in CORE XY (push-pull) configuration to minimize ringing and increase speed, and 2020 extruded aluminum frame with laser cut aluminum corner supports for rigidity. I have experimented with 3D printed supports, but frame was not stiff enough for my tastes.

This design is meant to be rigid, fast, and use minimal printed pieces.

Cost is ~$750 USD not including tax, shipping, and duties as applicable to your country.

Full design CAD files are available in Onshape (you need a free account to copy the design and edit yourself). All design files are exportable to .stl. For convenience, I have downloaded and rotated the stl's and posted them to Thingiverse here.

Onshape files are here.
--------------------------------https://cad.onshape.com/documents/58c0e9de910b980f78db313a/w/f2cc9715f90baade4735c223/e/94a5242ec921dd91f2257e06

For bill of materials, latest will always be posted here: https://docs.google.com/spreadsheets/d/1Hk-xcSfI6vfVNKvCDCkBKN79KrJszzolMjrFaeewW4o/edit?usp=sharing

For assembly, for now please consult the 3D model live in Onshape and the respective assemblies- frame, x, y, z, and e. This shows how the parts fit together. I will be creating an assembly guide, including mechanical, electrical, and software sections within the next few weeks.

I suggest not shopping around for cheaper 'core' items: rails, leadscrews, extruders, 3d printer controller (re-arm for ramps, and RAMPS 1.4 SB), these are cost optimized already, and are known good quality- stainless rails and leadscrews, good tolerances, reliable electronics. Go cheaper at your own risk, potentially compromising the entire design.

Updates and changes:

8/21/2017: Added e3D v6 bowden mount option for those that do not want to use the e3D v6 Titan direct drive option. One or two bowden mounts can be attached to the existing X Extruder Mount frame. New parts for printing a single bowden mount are: 1 x X Bowden Mount- X Bowden Mount Back, and 1 x X Bowden Mount- X Bowden Mount Front. BOM has been updated to reflect the options of Direct Drive or Bowden, and what parts to print.

8/21/2017: Deleted X to Y Mount- X to Y Mount Bottom and X to Y Mount- X to Y Mount Top, as they should not have been separated into two pieces. Added X to Y Mount as replacement. 2 x X to Y Mounts should be printed, one for left side of X axis, and one for right side of X axis. BOM has been updated to reflect the X to Y Change.

8/21/2017: It appears that the 3D printed spacers for the 694ZZ bearings used for the Y axis idlers are not working out. Suggest using some 0.5mm H x 5mm ID washers with a small outside ~6-7mm OD, and stacking them (3 on top, two in middle, 3 on bottom).

8/21/2017: The Z axis continuous belt is too long for proper tensioning by about 150mm. The positioning of the Z idlers on the Z Idler Mount will re-positioned to take up the slack- I will not know the actual design until build/test this weekend.

8/21/2017: The z axis Z Bearing Mount may not be thick enough to position the z trapezoidal lead screws straight vertically. If it looks like the trapezoidal lead screw will be forced to bend, use some washers to space it correctly vertically. I will test positioning this weekend, and will repost a thicker Z Bearing Mount if it looks like it is required.

8/28/2017: The Z Bed Mounting has changed- please see the Z section assembly in Onshape for changes and how components are assembled. There is no longer a requirement for countersunk holes in the build plate or holes in the heat bed mat (oversight!)- instead two M5 x 15mm OD washers are used to 'sandwich' the build plate from the outer edge, compressed and held by a spring below the build plate. Any large flat washers >15mm OD should do as long as they are not flexible and are heat resistant, although you want the ID to be about 5.3mm (to fit an M5 bolt). Added 'Z Bed Mount.stl' to the printable files. You will need to print out three for a complete bed mount. The three 2020 aluminum extrusions used for the bed mount have been shortened to accommodate the changes to 127mm (+Y) and 151mm (-X-Y, +X-Y). The center hole in the end of each extrusion requires tapping for an M5 screw. BOM has been updated with changes.

Printer:

Spiderbot.eu v1.1 Delta

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30% infill

Notes:

Parts are rotated and fully printed/tested without supports. Print in high strength PLA or PETG (I use APLA+ from 3D Fuel). I used 3 perimeters, and star infill pattern in Slic3R. Dimensions assume a properly calibrated printer.

Most parts have holes covered with 0.3mm skin to aid in bridging and remove need for support. Slic3r detects these nicely and bridges over them, not sure for other slicers. Remove/punch thru the skin to clear the hole prior to assembly.

This design is in Onshape, inspired by the CoreXY Frame (v2.0) design in solidworks from Lehaiver, which was imported and reverse engineered, and modified.

Design was changed to support M3 and M5 screws, avoiding M4, and adapted to work for a full 3D Printer instead of a fixed z axis laser cutter.

Special thanks go out to mzbot.us for the re-use of their unmodified spool holder design and cable management clips available here: https://github.com/mzbotreprap/VORON

comments.text:
The problem with ABS is mostly due to inability to control the following:
1) do not use part cooling fan on ABS, it will cause the part to crack/de-laminate as the part cools too quickly and creates areas of uneven stress.
2) use a heated bed 90-100C, leveled properly, and PEI build surface, and first layer with a 5mm brim to ensure good bed adhesion
3) control drafts- preferably use an enclosure to keep the build environment warm (50C) to lower stresses and minimize warping.
4) keep your parts compact with as large a solid footprint as possible (long skinny parts will warp). Most of the parts for the 5RAILS are a good solid compact footprint. The exception is the RAMPS case, which will be very difficult to print in ABS without warp. Would recommend PLA or PETG for that print.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: I'm already doing all that with 10% wood glue on the Ultimaker, and getting pretty good results. It was the guy who owns the printer that couldn't get ABS to work ;-)  (240c / 110c / 30% max fan)  With the wood glue the parts pop loose on their own the moment the bed cools, but are stuck solid while printing. It's freakin awesome. I will print the large and non-essential parts in PLA or PETG once my printer is working.  I'm printing your uploads now... thanks
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: Hi- the split in the x to y mount was part of an earlier design iteration, and looks like was left in as a mistake. I have suppressed it in the cad file now and will repost the stl this afternoon as one solid piece. Sorry for the damage to your leadscrews. If they are bent, they should be scrapped as they are impossible to straighten again. The z belt was difficult to determine length without building. I will see if the idlers can be repositioned to use this belt with proper tension. I have measured the Z belt, and it appears I used the belt from an earlier design iteration as well- the closest belt for the current design is 1140-2GT-6, which may come up a little short, but may work due to belt stretch and required tension. I will know this weekend. Do not order anything until I can test.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: My plan is to add a 2020 cross member to mount the Z idlers on that is further from the stepper. At least until the correct belt length could be acquired. But it's probably a perfectly viable solution long term anyway.
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: Yup that will work just fine.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: Question: If our build plate is exactly 300x300 (12 inch x 12 inch), and our heat pad is exactly 300x300, where are we attaching (drilling) the holes for mounting? Do we drill/tap the "edges" of the plate? I don't think the pad should have holes drilled in it.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: The current design requires the drilling of three countersunk holes in the build plate, with a PEI sheet layed over the top. Three M5 flat head bolts matching the countersunk are screwed with thumbnuts and springs from underneath. Look at the z bed detail assembly in Onshape for more detail. You are welcome to design different mounts if you wish.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: The OnShape drawing shows the three M5 screws going right through the silicone heat pad (that isn't shown). Are you planning to make holes in the heater and just cut the traces where the screws penetrate? How do you plan to insulate the broken wires from shorting on the screws? I ordered from your BOM, and I don't see any spots you can safely make M5 holes in the pad. Keenovo does offer an 11x11 pad, but it takes like 2 months to order one. And I only see a 110V version too.
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: Hmmm. You bring up a good point! Thanks for pointing it out. Looks like I will have to design some edge clamps instead of going thru the build platform. Stay tuned- this is of course still a work in progress!
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: Just pointing out that "edge clamps" are probably an issue if you want to use a glass plate on top. I'm still chewing on it, but with a 1/4 inch plate I think drilling or machining the edge is going to me best option unless I order the 11 inch heater. I'm actually wondering if even a 10 inch heater is plenty if you go with 120v and an SSR. I would think that thick aluminum plate would not remain cool round the edges for long with enough wattage. That's only a 1 inch unheated perimeter, and how often do you print to the edge of a 300mm build plate? A thinner plate would be a different fish kettle. Also saves my power supply, or lets me use a smaller one.
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: I have a 12x12 heated mat, so need to engineer something for myself edge to edge. The edge clamps cannot be 3d printed as the plate could easily reach 100C, where printed clamps would soften. Flatness of the surface is crucial- MIC6 aluminum is cast and machined flat. The type of aluminum is formulated to not warp under heat. Anything that size heated using different material will likely bow/warp. Borosilicate glass insulates, is prone to chipping, and is too expensive at 12x12. I still recommend MIC6 cast and machined aluminum. For clamps I am thinking two m5 ID 10 mm OD stainless washers- one on top of bed and one on bottom of bed to sandwich clamp the bed. The existing M5 bolts and springs can be used with these washers. A new m5 bolt mount on the ends of the 2020 extrusions used for bed support would extend the bolt past the bed so no holes need to be drilled in it.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: That sounds pretty good. I would probably use fender washers to spread the force on the heat pad. Do you think you can get the clamping force you need without damaging the heat pad? I would probably use large fiber washers as well in the sandwich. It would be nice at times to have a removable build surface you can stick in the freezer. I was thinking about edge drilling the plate and using 90 degree plain hanging hooks with thread down and the unthreaded straight part simply inserted in the hole. But your idea actually seems better.  I already have my glass plate BTW ;-)
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: I agree on the MIC6. But I have been having a bitch of a time finding an affordable one. Since I have this one now I will be checking to see how much it warps. I knew the clamps would need to be metal. If you use the bare aluminum what "surface" do you use. Do you polish it? Spray on? Paint on? Stick on?
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: On the bare aluminum, I would recommend a 0.8mm PEI sheet with 3M high temp double sided adhesive which works really well for ABS, PLA, and PETG. The surface never needs coating or replacing- just a very light sand with 00 steel wool to rejuvenate every once in a while. The other recommendation is in my BOM already under 'build plate skin' similar to a PEI sheet called Lokbuild, which comes with the adhesive backing.

comments.text: Parts should all be in by tonight. I'll probably start with unheated bed until issues are resolved. Can always cover up the holes with the heater later.

comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: I have not designed a Bowden mount for an e3d v6. Bowden extruders do not work well on larger printers due to the filament 'stretch/compression' in the long Bowden tube, causing stringing and zits on prints. A direct drive is preferable, but trade-off is weight. I balance the weight symmetrically on the carriage, and use 2020 beam to minimize vertical deflection/sag. You can do a single e3d v6 Titan direct drive or dual using the same x carriage mount. The Bowden mount on thingiverse you found will not work- you would have to modify the existing mount in Onshape for a Bowden.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: This is very close to what I have been circling around to for my first 3D printer. Are those the cheap linear guides or something like HiWin or MiSUMi? Did you consider using 4 sleds for Z? Where did you source the laser cut brackets? They have to be WAY better the those cast aluminum 90 degree 2 bolt things. Can't wait to see more. I just have my controller, steppers and 24v power supply so far.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: They are cheap linear guides, but from a good source- Robotdigg. I can vouch for them- stainless steel with smooth ball bearing movement. You could replace with costlier MGN12 guides and bearings from any source if you want. Four sleds for z over-constrains the design- all we need is two to keep the z plane from rotating. Since the support beam is also the center of the bed, cantilever is kept to a minimum (1/2 that of an end cantilever design). The laser cut brackets are also from Robotdigg as are most of the other components.  Complete component list with sources including web links are in the BOM spreadsheet.
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: I was thinking 2 sleds per rail on Z might help control twisting forces that those sleds are not designed for. Or the long version of the sled would also help that. MiSUMi offers rails with slight preload and longer sleds. It seems like that might be desirable. I'm not generally a fan of stainless for bearing surfaces if it can be avoided. Your BOM is very well done.
comments.author: thetekguy

comments.text: The design uses MGN12H long carriages. Stainless steel is stiff and does not rust- something you want to avoid with ball bearings and precision guides. The z axes rails are on either side of the bed- the distance between both z carriages resists twisting horizontally in the xy plane. The carriages are aligned so that the ball bearings are perpendicular to the twisting forces to bear the load properly. I am less concerned with vertical twisting, bit since there are ball bearings on either side of the carriage this is resisted nicely as well. If you want to modify the design, simply get yourself a free Onshape account, clone my design cad files, and use that as a starting point. I fully welcome any improvements or mods!
comments.author: mntbighker

comments.text: The x carriage has a microswitch  on the left side, and moves with the carriage as it slides on the x axis. You need to wire the x carriage anyways  for the hotend, extruder steppers so two extra endstop wires is  a not the end of the world. On left side x idler an m3 screw is settable as an adjustable endstop that triggers the microswitch as the x carriage moves to the far left. The y axes endstop is a microswitch fixed to the left y idler at the front of the frame. There is an m3 set screw on the left x idler that triggers the y microswitch as the left x idler slides to the front of the left y rail. The z microswitch is mounted to the top of the left z mgn12 rail and can be moved up and down in the t-slot to adjust. As the bed moves up, the mgn12 carriage bumps up against the microswitch mounted to the left z rail. Use the online Onshape CAD files to see how these endstop are mounted and assembled. Zoom into the x, y, and z assembly tabs for detail. Homing is to minimum- zero, zero, zero. In your slicer you then need to offset your print area x and y in Cartesian space to match the edge of the printable bed area, and set your maximums for x y and z in software, as there are no endstops for this.
comments.author: thetekguy

description.text:
What? You're already bored with your plain old fidget spinner? This gravity-driven fidget spinner should provide you with minutes more of spinning entertainment!

To get it going, you flip the spinner so that the bearing is at the bottom of the twisty shaft. Then pinch on the bearing holder so that it grabs the nut in the inner bearing race. Gravity will pull the mass downward, giving it a good spin at the same time. Now the tricky part: just before it reaches the bottom, release the pressure on the bearing holder and the bearing can now spin freely. Flip it over and do it again and again (and again)!

https://youtu.be/vSB0odbDI4k

Printer Brand:

MakerGear

Printer:

MakerGear M2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

20%

Notes:

Print 1 shaft, 1 bearing holder, 1 nut, and 2 penny holders.

The shaft is very tall and skinny, so I've included a built-in support tower to keep it steady while printing. After printing, just break-away the support tower and sand down any nubs left on the shaft.

Assembly

In addition to the 3D printed parts, you will need:

1 608 skate bearing (remove shields/seals and clean out any oil or grease)
18 pennies
2 drops superglue

  1. Insert 3 pennies into each slot of both the upper and lower penny holders
  2. Insert the nut into the bore of your bearing. It should be a nice friction fit. If it is too loose, shim it with a piece of thin tape.
  3. Insert the bearing into the bearing holder so that the larger diameter hub of the nut is positioned between the two pincher tabs of the bearing holder.
  4. Work the nut up and down on the twisted shaft to make sure it slides smoothly.
  5. Put a drop of superglue on one end of the shaft and screw it into one of the penny holders.
  6. Slide the bearing assembly onto the shaft.
  7. Put a drop of superglue on the other end of the shaft and screw it into the other penny holder.

You are now ready to spin! (See description above for how to make it go.)

Deutsch:

Das Projekt PistenBully entstand an Weihnachten 2016, als wir so einem Monster bei der Arbeit zugeschaut haben. Die Idee ist eigentlich, dass der Bully irgendwann noch eine Schneefräse und Anbauteile bekommt.

Das Design ist angelehnt an den PistenBully 300 und 600 der Firma Kässbohrer – ich hoffe die sind mir jetzt nicht zu böse dafür.

Das Design ist simpel, alle Komponenten können in PLA und TPU selber gedruckt werden. Stützmaterialien: entweder selber machen oder meine Designs entsprechend verwenden. Spezialfall ist die Kabine. Hierbei habe ich bereits einen Druckkeil für den oberen Kabinenbereich modelliert, welcher nach dem Druck entfernt werden kann. Somit ist nur noch Stützmaterial für den unteren Teil notwendig. Alles weitere inkl. der für die entsprechenden Bauetappe notwendigen Komponenten werden in der Montageanleitung aufgezeigt.

Das notwendige Equipment habe ich inklusive der Lager von Banggood geordert. Gibt’s aber auch bequem beim Händler vor Ort…

Viel Spass beim bauen und truxen…

...

English:

The project PistenBully was started at Christmas 2016 while we watched a monster at work. The idea actually is to get also some snowmill and attachments for it.

My design is based on the PistenBully 300 and 600 Kässbohrer - I hope they are not too angry on me therefor. But they’re really cool!!

The construction is simple, all components can be printed in PLA and TPU. You can choose to do the support by yourself or use the one I’ve done in the designs. Except for the cabin. However, I have already modeled a part for the upper cabin area, which can be removed after printing. So support only for the lower part is necessary. All further details are shown in the assembly instructions (PDF).

I’ve ordered my equipment including the bearings at Banggood. But it is also available at your local dealer...

Have fun and enjoy!

title: HPI Racing Savage XS Flux - Steering connecting rod #105296

description.text:
The steering broke on my Savage XS during its maiden trip to my garden. The item in question is the steering rod which connects the servos to the wheel assembly. So I designed it in Fusion 360, and printed it in nylon.

The original part was 57mm in length but I found it to be a little short, making the wheels geometry misaligned. I've made the latest version 59mm long, which is a better fit.

I also deepened the ball joints grooves, and reduced the diameter for the opening to the ball joint, for better hold under stress.

Printer:

Anet A8

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.15

Infill:

100

Notes:

Nylon is a hard material to print. I use taulman3D 645 so I followed the manufacturer's recommended settings which were:

  • 245°C print temp
  • 40mm/s print speed
  • outer shell layer first, inner shell next
  • Bed 60°C

With these settings, the direction column came about right and snapped right in place, just like the original did. Very pleased with the result. If only HPI (& others) would provide STL files for replacement parts...

description.text:
In our new kitchen (IKEA metod) we have an inner drawer that was ment to be following the outer drawer out when that is drawn out.

Unfortunately, such mechanism did not seem bo be available from IKEA, so I designed my own latch. It works by gravity, and clicks nicely into locked position when the drawer is closed.

Printer Brand:

Wanhao

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator i3 Plus

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2

Infill:

45

Notes:

I printed the base rail laying flat, and the latch standing on it's top. This way the need for support is eliminated, except for a tiny bot of support under the countersunk screwhole in the base.

I created a beer gyroscopic stabilizer since I found that the original was only good for closed cans.

NOTE: I have made this much larger than I thought, I will re-upload a newer design once I have evaluated my print.

comments.text: Love it!  Was thinking about this for a long time and was going to patent it but seems like they're already out there..  Anyway, the purpose of this is so that when you're playing gigs or setting up your stage you can have your beverage at the ready and then when you have to bend down to adjust levels on pedals or whatever it doesn't spill all over your equipment.  That way I don't have to load down my mic stand.  Also I can do back flips and not spill a drop.  How do I get one?  I don't have a 3D printer.

title: Top Plate for Heavy Duty Shelf

description.text:
I have some heavy duty shelf and wanted to mount one single wood panel over two of them.
But on top there is no mounting support and the top metal would be pressed over time into the wood. I used a caliper for measuring the dimensions. The dimensions for the shelf feet/top are outside 35 mm, inside 33 mm (begin of rounded edge) and thickness 2 mm.
I used Tinkercad to made me some top plates, here https://tinkercad.com/things/ihwzqjECMqD you can find the thing.
I made three Versions one without a hole, the second with a hole where you can use a washer and third with a milled hole, so you can use wood screws.

Geeetech Prusa i3 Pro X

No

The other interesting thing is I designed the chain to be printed pre assembled.
comments.author: TuxSoft

comments.text: In the opposite direction, my model also does not bend (not significantly, and conceived) due to a longer bottom platform. I considered the whole print variant of the link, but in my model there are no surfaces for printing in the air or with supports. In this way, the surfaces are smooth and do not require any processing, but there is a minus - after printing the links need to be assembled-glued, but this is a minor drawback, as I think.
comments.author: TuxSoft

comments.text: Its possible to get good bridges that don't have loops and sags when printing, depending on your filament you could try the opposite to quick logic and try slow your bridges down to maybe 20mm/sec and perhaps even have the fan on 100%. I can not imagine having to glue and assemble each link bit by bit. Perhaps a click fit would be an option.

title: Dis-Enchanter
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a mostly working chanter for the Great Highland Bagpipes!

Though I have successfully made a functional chanter, it is NOT as simple as 'download-and-print.' There are a number of adjustments that must be made and several iterations to go through.

If you want to make one, check with me to make sure you get the latest version. I'd love an automated way to upload here when I commit to git.
See the included instructions
I designed this chanter using by copying the 1970's Hardie chanter that I am so fond of. I found the basic measurements online and used them as a starting point.

** HOW TO DO THIS **

DIS-ENCHANTER

Warnings

  • This is not a simple "download-and-print" item. Not only is it a work in progress,
    but once completed it will still take several rounds to make a successful print.

  • The Bagpipe does NOT tune like modern instruments. It does not use halfsteps, but rather uses fractional increments between notes. See the tuning.html file for more specifics.

Required tools and knowledge

  • Understanding of bagpipe tuning.

  • Functional Great Highland Chanter reed

  • Small hand-end files. An emery board may work.

  • ABS - ABS is less fragile for this work. PLA snaps too easily along the layer-lines.

  • An understanding of Cura. This model was designed around the Cura slicer. While other sliders will work, it is important to know what settings are chosen and why.

  • Drill bits

  • Tuner that displays true frequency, not just the cents off. Does not have to be specific for Highland tuning.

Step 1: Get the files

I am assuming if you are reading this document, that you have the files already.

Step 2: Calibrate

Step 2.1: Reset starting values

Decide what pitch you would like to make the chanter. In this example, 472. Set both BASE_FREQUENCY and TARGET_FREQUENCY to that value.

Once the first chanter is printed, it won't be at the pitch you like. Most likely it will be way, way low. Once you determine the pitch of the first chanter, you'll be able change the pitch here and print a second chanter that should be near the correct pitch.

BASE_FREQUENCY = 455;
TARGET_FREQUENCY = 472;

Step 2.2: Determine the 'kerf'

Because the chanter is too large for my printer to handle, it must be broken into two pieces. Edit the dis-enchatered.scad file and find the line that says PIECE = and change the value to 3. This will print a make a test object to see how well the pieces fit together.

Edit the kerf value according to the docs until you get a snug fit.

You will need to do some filing on the pieces as that joint is designed to print horizontally instead of vertically.

Step 2.3: Ensure the throat is the right size.

A 5/16 drill bit should fit snugly. Currently no short cut in printing out just the throat. I just stood watch over the printer and flipped the switch at the correct time.

Step 3: Print the bottom half

Edit the PIECE = value and set it to 1. Render and export the STL file as bottom.stl

I used Cura as my slicer and there a few settings that need to be set.

Set the 'Shell Thickness' to 5 mm. While this will be almost the same as 100% infill, Cura does the infill as concentric circles which appear to much stronger.

Step 4: Print the top half

Edit the PIECE = value and set it to 2

For the top half, it is important to choose Supports to be Touching Buildplate and Platform Adhesion Type to be Brim.

In addition, I found coating my build-plate in glue-stick to be the only way to keep the things from falling over.

I added a small plastic buffer around the seal -- or the very most top of the chanter. This buffer is designed to keep the support structure off the chanter body itself.

Step 5: Assembly

  • Remove the support structures from the top of the chanter.

  • File the joint down until it fits properly.

  • Assemble the two pieces carefully. At this point I smother the joint in hot glue, then wrap with electrical tape to make it air tight. Be careful as the joint itself is physically weak and snaps with too much pressure.

Step 6: Add reed and play.

Add the reed to your new chanter and balance the A's.

Measure the pitch of your low A and adjust the BASE_FREQUENCY value. Re-print the chanter and assemble.

Step 7: Testing the chanter

During my first experiment, the chanter came out quite well and was mostly in tune.

However, both F and G pitched extremely low and I could not use a regular Bagpipe tuner.

There is an HTML file that comes with these instructions. Enter the pitch of the chanter into that spreadsheet and it will display the correct frequency for the other notes on the scale.

Regular tuning rules apply as well as the possibility of needing to undercut one of the holes.

Step 8: Fine tuning

There is the option of making manual adjustments to the tone hole locations and moving them up or down as needed to do fine adjustments.

I've not quite reached this stage yet.

comments.text: Yes, mainly because if you look closely, the heater throat screws into a huge bar, which will wick the heat away much better than a heatsink that may or may not get good contact with it.  It also allows for much better airflow over that bar and the entire metal frame of the MK8 (moving air removes more heat that static air (think fan in radiator or AC system), with the added benefit of now there is an airflow path over the extruder motor as well.

comments.text: Got a similar question: I assume that the magnets used will have to be diametrically magnetized, but I'd like to confirm which magnetization direction you used? Also: I find myself in the situation that I can either get 6mm or 8mm diameter magnets. I lean more towards 8mm as the magnet would touch the tube at a lower point and makes me a bit more flexible with low volumes. Is there some space between the magnets and the tubes in your design or do the magnets touch exactly? In the latter case I will either build up the 'thing' a bit higher, or set the magnets deeper.
comments.author: Manooo

comments.text: The axis along which the magnets switch polarity seems to be the long axis of the cylinder, but ampure beads are paramagnetic, so I don't think it matters much. Wider magnets would certainly make sense for the reason you give, that's the way I'd go. The magnets touch the wells because that's actually where the plate rests--the wells don't touch the surface of the magnet plate, just the tops of the magnets (although it looks pretty close in the picture). I don't think you'd have to deepen the wells for a wider magnet--a higher magnet top would just suspend the plate higher, which wouldn't affect the plate's effectiveness.

This thing is a cover that blocks the daylight from reaching the daylight sensor on top of the dash of Ford cars, SUVs and trucks.
On newer Ford cars, SUVs and trucks, there is a daylight sensor on the dashboard that turns on the headlights to about 80% power (DRLs, or "Daytime Running Lights"), and prevents the fill-in lights from turning on in the daytime.
I like to have lots of light coming from the front of my car in the daytime so other drivers can see me coming more easily.
Placing this cover over the sensor will cause the headlights to be at full power, and will allow the fill-in lights to be turned on in daylight conditions.
You could use electrical tape to cover over the daylight sensor on your car, or you can print this cool cover on your MakerBot, Thing-O-Matic, Replicator, or variant.
I designed this cover to fit the sensor on my 2008 Ford Expedition.  It also fits on the sensor on my wife's 2011 Ford Edge.  I'm not sure how far back Ford used this same sensor.  If your sensor looks like it is a shape that this cover will fit, then I guess you're in luck!
I printed this on the Thing-O-Matic at TechShop, and also on my Replicator, and it seems to print pretty well at just about any settings that work for other items.

1.)  Print this file on your MakerBot, Thing-O-Matic, Replicator, or variant,
2.)  Place the printed thing over the daylight sensor on your dashboard in your Ford car, SUV or truck.
3.)  Use these new powers responsibly!
You may want to use a small square of foam VHB or mounting tape to keep it from moving.

If you'd like to read about the project, see:

http://www.creatorsstudio.org/special-projects/category/marble-run

Most of these models were designed to print without supports. I used a Lulzbot Taz 6 with either PLA or NGEN filament. Magnets were glued on to the pieces afterward.

A pair of triangular faces which can be glued together to form a tube.
This is an example of large objects being assembled from smaller parts.
Errata - the original tritube.stl had the inner tube out of round.
Today (5-march-2014) I replaced it with a better one.
Opps, another version 6-march.

The basic part is a triangular shell.
Assume the tube is standing upright for now,
There are two long side and one short.
The short side will be on the ground.
The two faces which abut on the side are not flat.
This is why there are two types.
To alternate them there are some dots near the short face.
These dots should go on the same side - all left or all right.
All the triangle in the first row (pointing up) will be the same.
The next row (pointing down) will be the "other" type.
See the included scale model for guidance.
The basic part can be printed laying down or standing.
The domed variant is best printed standing.
There are 12 triangles per layer.
The "solid" variants can be printed with very little fill - I've found 3% works for the dome and 6% for flat.
Small case for a DC-DC Step Down with Pin Header to distribute voltage.

title: Fidget Spinner - low friction - no bearing! - fullprintable

description.text:
Hi guys!
This is my fidget spinner full printable with very low friction!
The mechanism is a compromise between minimum contact surfaces and center shaft resistance.

The 2 most important printing parameters are:

  • 90/95% to maintain high weight.
  • 5 line of perimeters to prevent holes in the center shaft.

The material used is PLA easyfill by Formfutura, https://www.waxplast.com/store/p97/EasyFil%E2%84%A2__-_PLA.html

The assembly is simple,
Smooths moving surfaces
Lock the disc to the shaft with a drop of glue
I did not make a joint To avoid fragile parts.

title: Bacterial Flagellum structure from S. typhimurium

description.text:
Structure of the bacterial flagellum extracted from S. typhimurium cells.

These are the original files for the structure is described on figure 1 in this publication: http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S096098220602286X

David DeRosier, Bacterial Flagellum: Visualizing the Complete Machine , Current Biology, Volume 16, Issue 21, 2006, Pages R928-R930, ISSN 0960-9822, http://dx.doi.org/10.1016/j.cub.2006.09.053.

Abstract: Electron tomography of frozen-hydrated bacteria, combined with single particle averaging, has produced stunning images of the intact bacterial flagellum, revealing features of the rotor, stator and export apparatus.

The original files are made available by courtesy of David DeRosier and Dennis Thomas.
The color model print picture was taken from https://www.flickr.com/photos/[email protected]/315702098
Figure 1 form the article "Bacterial Flagellum: Visualizing the Complete Machine In Situ", whose original files are made available

This structure is discussed in the article:
http://www.sciencedirect.com/science/article/pii/S096098220602286X#bibliography0005 Related published structures include EMD-1100, EMD-1235 and EMD-1224. This material is suited for a structural biology course.
Printing notes The model STL can be printed in one color using an FFF or SLA printer, or in full color using the WRL file on a binder jet printer.

title: Eachine 1000TVL Camera Housing for use with RealACC x210

description.text:
This is a camera housing for the Eachine 1000TVL camera that allows for it to be mounted in the RealACC x210 Quadcopter frame using M3 bolts and Nuts.

I was inspired by Quadkiller's awesome design here: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1715354

The dimensions that I used for the original design (V1) can be found here: https://drive.google.com/open?id=0B-5wcayyUhJWSmZhRld1OXgtSk0

Edit (2017-06-09): V1 is too big to fit between the gap in the top plate of the RealACC frame. It's also quite bulky so I've reworked it to be less bulky and it is file V1a.

Edit (2017-07-25) - Added V2.stl which is a narrower lighter version so that the camera can have greater variance in angle and clear the RealACC carbon frame.

Edit (2017-08-11) - Added V3.stl which has the bolt holes placed higher so that the flight angle can be greatly adjusted. Peyton370z mentioned that he modified mine so that he could get a 45 degree camera angle. Peyton370z didn't post a re-mix and I liked the idea so I added a version myself which I am now using on my quad. I've also renamed the files so that they are a bit less confusing.

Printer Brand:

Tinkertine Studio

Printer:

Ditto +

Yes

10

Printed with 4 shells and minimal infill. Support and brim/raft might not be necessary when printing with the lens opening oriented down. The fit is very snug.

Hi!
these are models for the holes on the dash of a 1979-1983 Datsun 280zx, next to the defrost vents, where the screws that hold the dash are.
They are a direct, measure by measure reproduction of the real ones.
They fit right in, I've tried them. I don't know how I'd get them out, the clips would probably break when you`d pry them, but then, you can print more!
I've printed them face down, and they print good, even the little clips' overhang. The only issue is that there is a step on the top part, where the middle is higher than the surroundings; that prints badly because it's trying to print a 3mm horizontal overhang. It looks weird when you look at it from close by, but from a foot or two away it just looks like texture in the plastic which in the end is pretty ok! Maybe if it's be printed right side up, but then, you'd need a ton of supports for everything, since it's just like a table with 2 legs that touch, and two that don't even touch the floor (the little cones that locate the cap in the hole).

***Quick note, mine are in black PLA, and have warped afew a week or two in the sun... it's not bad, it just makes them loose. no problem taking them out anymore, but they have a slight curve to them now.
might want to to print out of ABS or Petg

title: Spark plug wire separator 6 cyl (8mm wire)

description.text:
Hi!

I made these for my straight 6 engine. They fit perfectly for 8mm wires, and aren't too hard to clip in. (I also made these a few hours later: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2374330. That version is much nicer looking, and looks like a closed block around the wires)

There is a 6 notch separator for when the wires are closer to the distributor, and then a 3 wire separator (with more room between the wires) for between that first organiser and the plugs themselves.

This NEEDS TO BE MADE OF ABS. I just made them out of PLA and after one drive, the engine's heat warped them all and the wires came out of them. that's why I have no photos; that happened before I took any.

description.text:
This is a drawing robot or pen plotter machine designed around 2020 aluminum extrusions. It uses a coreXY movement for precise fast moves. [More info on CoreXY here: http://corexy.com/theory.html]. The design goals were to create a reliable, easy to print and build coreXY platform that could be used with pens for drawing or laser modules for cutting and etching.

Here is a video of an early test, sorry for the focus and lighting ;-)
https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=97m4MML1zPs&t=81s

Another video
https://youtu.be/fN6t37Ey4qE

Firmware for the Arduino
https://github.com/robottini/grbl-servo
Make sure to edit the your "config.h" in the /Arduino/libraries/grbl folder to enable CoreXY.
Use Gcode command M03 S90 to lower the pen; Use Gcode command M5 to raise the pen.
NOTE: This design will also work an Arduino MEGA and RAMPS 1.4 or any other CNC/3D printer controller that supports CoreXY and servos.

Inkscape which is free
https://inkscape.org/en/

Inkscape GCode plugin MI Inkscape Extension
http://www.mediafire.com/file/ae0wquqornzc3o2/MI+Inkscape+Extension.zip
The plugin is easier to use than the built in GCode Tools in Inkscape.

Source Rabbit G Code Sender
https://www.sourcerabbit.com/GCode-Sender/
Or
Universal G Code Sender
https://winder.github.io/ugs_website/

HARDWARE
(for a work area of approximately 300mm x 200mm)
2 X 2020 Extrusion x 450mm, X axis frame
2 X 2020 Extrusion x 350mm, Y axis frame
1 X 2020 Extrusion x 325mm, Y axis carriage
NOTE: For different sized machines. The travel distance on the Y axis will be about 120mm less than the length of the Y axis frame length. The travel distance on the X axis is about 150mm less than the length of the X axis frame length.

XY Axis
2 X Nema 17
2 X GT2 Pulley 20 teeth
2 X 1500mm GT2 belt
12 X Printed Pulleys or Upgrade to GT2 pulleys with bearings or use 2 F623ZZ flange bearings front-to-front per pulley

Z Axis
1 X Servo sg90 micro-servo
2 X 75mm x 3mm rods (from CD_Rom or other smooth rods), Z Axis
1 X ballpoint pen spring

20 X M5 x 10mm screws
20 X M5 extrusion nuts (slide-in or drop-in)
7 X M3 x 28mm screws (The pulley's also work well with finish nails)
16 X M3 x 8mm screws
1 X M3 x 12mm screw (You can also supper glue the Belt Clamp to the CarriageBeltSide)
misc M3 nuts and washers

Zip-Tie 5mm wide zip-tie (cut 4 X 10mm long pieces to use as locking wedges for the belt clip)
~150mm UHMW Polyethylene Film Tape or Teflon tape. This tape is used on the inside surfaces of the XYJoiner and the carriage to reduce friction. It can be found at hardware stores and is used on drawer slides. This is optional however it is highly recommended.
https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B00XK9V9ZS/ref=oh_aui_detailpage_o03_s00?ie=UTF8&psc=1
I used it only on the small pads that touch the 2020 extrusion. Your carriage and XYJoiners should slide easily along the 2020 extrusion, if it is too tight file or sand the pads on the printed parts until it slides easily.

Electronics
Arduino Uno
CNC Shield
2 X Pololu A4988 stepper driver (with 6 jumpers @ 16x microstepping)
12V 2A Wall Transformer

Printed Parts
1 X 2020_DB_Belt clamp
1 X 2020_DB_CarriageBeltSide
1 X 2020_DB_CarriageMountSide
2 X 2020_DB_CornerMotor
2 X 2020_DB_CornerMotorTop
4 X 2020_DB_CornerPulley
2 X 2020_DB_Foot
1 X 2020_DB_Pen holder ver8
2 X 2020_DB_xyJoiner (top and bottom)
12 X 2020_DB_belt_pulley and spacers
(Upgrade to GT2 pulleys with bearings or use 2 F623ZZ flange bearings per pulley)

July 13, 2017: I have updated the pen holder with a new design utilizing 3mm x 75mm smooth rods liberated from an old CD/DVD ROM. This design is a little more ridged than the original design.

Building Tips:
Lay everything out on a table and test fit the parts together to make sure you have everything and have an idea of how it should go together. Put the UHMW Polyethylene film tape on the pads of the sliding components and make sure that they slide smoothly. file or sand the pads down if they do not move easily.

Check the electronics to make sure everything is working. Don't forget to add the three jumpers under each of the stepper drivers.

Check the 5mm holes, if the screws don't go through easily drill them out. Most of the 3mm screw holes are small so the screw threads will bite into the plastic. Be careful that you do not over tighten and strip the plastic. If you do you can use a drop of supper glue to hold the screw in place.

Attach the stepper motors to the motor mounts, and note which way you want the wires to face, before building the frame.

The X motor is on the right and the belt for it should be on the top, the black wire should be plugged in toward the center of the board. The Y motor belt should be on the bottom, the blue wire should be toward the center of the board.

Assemble the frame before trying to put the belts in, leave the motor covers off until you have the belts installed and lined up.

Printer:

HyperCube

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.2mm

Infill:

30% or better

Notes:

Use 3 or more layers top bottom and sides. You should only need to use supports on the XYJoiners and CarriageBeltSide and CarriageMountSide.

comments.text: Alright. I'm having some minor issues at this point.  In particular, the SG90 micro servo doesn't appear to have enough torque to hold up the pen spring on the metal rods. It will push it up, but when the servo gets turned off, the pen gets pushed back down onto the drawing surface by the force of the springs, pushing the unpowered servo back down. I've tried using different combinations of spring lengths without  much success. Any ideas?

title: IKEA Chair Wheel
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
These chair wheels were made to replace my misplaced IKEA chair wheels. They fit perfectly for a 10 mm diameter stem. Disclaimer:
This is just a model. They will not support your weight. I am actively working on re-designing this so that it might support a person.

Bill of Materials: 2x "new wheel"
1x "connector"
1x "wheel shaft"
1x "revised middle wheel" As of right now, the "middle wheel" still needs to be printed with supports--for best results, print on the flat end. Multiply this by 5 if you'd like your chair to have five wheels. I printed in PLA in low quality. Some drilling may be necessary around some of the holes if the shafts are not fitting, or you may upgrade to a higher quality print. These are intended to snap together, with some application of force (I might suggest a few taps with a hammer, but be careful).

description.text:
A new tile set to add some diversity to your towns and cities!

The pieces are designed to work with Dnd miniatures and on a 25mm x 25mm grid.

Threednd stone walls fit perfect with threednd tavern walls and floor. Also add two roof pieces to make small houses!

Social

If you like my models please consider tipping or check out my Patreon page. These help with the wasted plastic prototypes and time trying to make these models perfect.

Also check out my Instagram or Facebook for fun DnD and 3D printing pictures!

I am also available for freelance work specializing in board game and rpg pieces.

Note:

These pieces have more detail then past pieces so print slower to keep the boards from getting wavy.

A new tile set to add some diversity to your towns and cities!

The pieces are designed to work with Dnd miniatures and on a 25mm x 25mm grid.

Threednd stone walls fit perfect with threednd tavern walls and floor. Also add two roof pieces to make small houses!

Social

If you like my models please consider tipping or check out my Patreon page. These help with the wasted plastic prototypes and time trying to make these models perfect.

Also check out my Instagram or Facebook for fun DnD and 3D printing pictures!

I am also available for freelance work specializing in board game and rpg pieces.

Note:

These pieces have more detail then past pieces so print slower to keep the boards from getting wavy.

title: Maker Select v2 Z axis Bearing Mounts

description.text:
previously I created a set of X-ends for the Monoprice Maker Select v2 to replace the stock metal ones because I wanted a way to use standard LM8UU bearings for the z-axis. Those have been installed on my printer for the last couple of months, but I figured I'd try making a set of bearing holders in case any of you want to use different bearings, but are happy with the metal x-ends that your printer came with.

These seem to work pretty well. Just screw them in from the bottom, slide the bearing into place, and you should be good to go.

I printed these in ABS with 4 perimeters and 40% infill, but the walls are pretty thin so you could probably do them 100% infill and it wouldn't make much difference in print time.
